title: 1998 AHSME Problem 1
body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"image","attrs":{"src":"/brilliantexport/brioche/solvable/e7ed7c4b9b.1137eb573d.8u154b.png?width=250"}},{"type":"text","text":"\nEach of the sides of five congruent rectangles is labeled with an integer. In rectangle A, w = 4, x = 1, y = 6, z = 9. In rectangle B, w = 1, x = 0, y = 3, z = 6. In rectangle C, w = 3, x = 8, y = 5, z = 2. In rectangle D, w = 7, x = 5, y = 4, z = 8. In rectangle E, w = 9, x = 2, y = 7, z = 0. These five rectangles are placed, without rotating or reflecting, in position as below. Which of the rectangle is the top leftmost one?"}]}]}

title: 1998 AHSME Problem 10
body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"image","attrs":{"src":"/brilliantexport/brioche/solvable/e7ed7c4b9b.28555b6e3b.VaTgyI.png?width=250"}},{"type":"text","text":"\nA large square is divided into a small square surrounded by four congruent rectangles as shown. The perimter of each of the congruent rectangles is 14. What is the area of the large square?"}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"let "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"b"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" be the measurements of 2 non congruent sides of the rectangle. Then, 
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"P=2(a+b)=14"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a+b=7"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"From the figure above, the measure of a side of the bigger square can be expressed as "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a+b"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" ,which is equal to 7. Hence, the area of the bigger square is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(a+b)^{2}=7^{2}=\boxed{49}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Each rectangle will have length 5 and width 2  cm. So total side vlength is 7 Cm
so area of square is 7X7 =49 Ans
K.K.GARG,India"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

title: 1998 AHSME Problem 11
body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Let R be a rectangle. How many circles in the plane of R have a diameter both of whose endpoints are vertices of R?"}]}]}

comments.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            After reading the comment by Harsh Depal for a few times, I only understand what he means and reason why the answer is five.
Let the rectangular be ABCD, I guessed 6 because of 4C2, of course.
[AB,AC,AD,BC,BD,CD]
But, the circle with diameter AC and BD are same.
Hence, only 5 circles.
(Both circle with diameter AC and BD have the same radius and origin at the intercept of diagonals of rectangular)

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

title: 1998 AHSME Problem 12
body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"How many different prime numbers are factors of N if "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\\log_2 (\\log_3 (\\log_5 (\\log_7 N)))"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" = 11?"}]}]}

title: 1998 AHSME Problem 13
body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Walter rolls four standard six-sided dice and finds that the product of the numbers of the upper faces is 144. Which of he following could not be the sum of the upper four faces?"}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Possible combinations for product 144"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a) 6 4 2 3 Sum:16"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"b) 6 3 4 4 Sum: 17"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"c) 2 3 4 6 Sum: 15"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"So, 18 is violated"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Possible Combination for product 144"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a) 4 3 4 3 Sum: 14"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"b) 6 4 2 3 Sum:15"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"c) 6 6 2 2 Sum: 16"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"d) 6 6 4 1 Sum:17"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"So 18 is the out of the equation."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

title: 1998 AHSME Problem 14
body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A parabola has vertex of (4,-5) and has two x-intercepts, one positive, and one negative. If this parabola is the graph of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"y = ax^{2} + bx + c"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", which of a,b, and c must be positive?"}]}]}

title: 1998 AHSME Problem 15
body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A regular hexagon and an equilateral triangle have equal areas. What is the ratio of the length of a side of the triangle to the length of a side of the hexagon?"}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The hexagon consists of 6 equilateral triangles of side b. 
If the area of one of those is B, the hexagon's area is 6 B. "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The triangle consists of 4 equilateral triangles of side a/2. 
Call the area of each one A, so the area of the triangle is 4A. 
For the triangle it's ( a * a sqrt(3) / 2 ) (from Pythagorean Theorem on 30-60-90 triangle), 
and for the hexagon it's ( 6 * b * b sqrt(3) / 2 ) 
Setting those equal we have: a^2 sqrt(3) / 2 = 6 b^2 sqrt(3) / 2 
a^2 = 6 b^2 
a = sqrt(6) b ( take square roots ) 
a/b = sqrt(6)."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

title: 1998 AHSME Problem 16
body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"image","attrs":{"src":"/brilliantexport/brioche/solvable/e7ed7c4b9b.d5e7a27eff.oSOdGC.png?width=250"}},{"type":"text","text":"\nThe figure shown is the union of a circle and two semicircles of diameters a and b, all of whose centers are collinear. The ratio of the area, of the shaded region to that of the unshaded region is"}]}]}

title: 1998 AHSME Problem 17
body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Let f(x) be a function with the two properties:
(a) for any two real numbers x and y, f(x+y) = x + f(y), and
(b) f(0) = 2."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"What is the value of f(1998)?"}]}]}

title: 1998 AHSME Problem 18
body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A right circular cone of volume A, a right circular cylinder of volume M, and a sphere of volume C all have the same radius, and the common height of the cone and the cylinder is equal to the diameter of the sphere. Then:"}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"volume of the cylinder is πr²h and the volume of the cone is πr²h/3, so 3A=M. 
The volume of the sphere is 4πr³/3, and h=2r, then C=2πr²h/3, C=2A.
With A-M+C=0, we can get into A-3A+2A=0 wich is the correct answer."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

replies.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            yea thanks, the diameter of the sphere (2r) equals the height of the other solids

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"

                                            because r in sphere is the height also.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"
